***Graduation update: Practice, TICKET, and Parking Information***

Graduation practice will be held on Monday, June 1st, and Tuesday, June 2nd, from 9 a.m. - 11 a.m. Students should park behind the field house and adhere to social distancing guidelines. Students may wear shorts and T-shirts but must meet the school dress code.

At the conclusion of practice on Monday, we will conduct a lottery. Each student will draw a number. This number will dictate the order that the students draw their seat numbers. Each student will then draw another number that represents where in the stadium their 8 tickets will be located. The tickets will be dispersed on Tuesday at the conclusion of practice. If students acquire tickets from any other students, those guests must sit in the designated area on their ticket.

For graduation on June 4th, only seniors will park in the parking lot behind the field house. All other guests must park in the student parking lot or in front of the school.

Please contact the guidance office if you have any questions.

Graduation Ceremony Update:

Graduation ceremonies for the Hawkinsville High School class of 2020 will be held on Thursday, June 4th, at Bobby Gentry Stadium. The ceremony will begin at 7:30 PM. We have chosen to have it on Thursday so that we can use Friday and Saturday as alternative dates for the ceremony if weather conditions effectively force a postponement. Ordinarily, the gym is utilized as the backup; in this case, we do not have an indoor facility that can safely host the guests who will be in attendance. Guests will be limited. No one will be admitted without an invitation to attend.

We do apologize for the limitations, but we must endeavor to provide our students and their chosen guests a safe environment in this very important event. The event will be streamed live. Streaming details will be provided as soon as they are available.

Respectfully,

Al Pollard, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Pulaski County Schools

Broad Street Baptist Church
March 27 at 8:53 AM ·

Broad Street Church members and Hawkinsville Community,

The report on Shelly this morning is that he is stable but his situation is still critical. The nurse was very direct with Vonnie this morning and said that it is too early to tell how this is going to go. She is only able to call the hospital to check on him once a shift change so the hospital is not bombarded with calls. The updates will be slow in coming.

This tells us that Shelly is not in the hands of doctors, nor in the hands of nurses, nor in our hands, but in God's hands, which is exactly where we want him to be. In fact, it is exactly where he would want to be. We definitely need to pray for the doctors and nurses as they care for Shelly and other patients, but all the time knowing that God is in charge. As this situation goes on, there is the temptation to pray less and move on to other things. Life must go on, but we can still "pray without ceasing" throughout the day for Shelly, Vonnie, and family! Stay positive and stay prayerful! I'll give updates as they come.

Pastor Jeff Waters

CCRPI Report

Pulaski County Schools have had significant progress in the past two years on CCRPI results. CCRPI is the instrument used by the state of Georgia to evaluate schools' and districts' academic performance. CCRPI results were first issued in 2012. The state has changed the standards frequently. This past year was the second year that schools and districts were measured by the same criteria. Pulaski County increased its score from 68.0 in 2018 to 75.4 in 2019 which represents a 10.9% increase. Pulaski County was the eighth-highest scoring district in 2018 in the Heart of Georgia RESA. We have moved to the fifth-highest scoring district for 2019 scores. It should be noted that only four-tenths of a point separated Pulaski from the third-place position in the RESA.

When compared to the Middle Georgia RESA, Pulaski County would have finished as the third-highest scoring district with only Monroe and Houston being higher. Please see the 2018 and 2019 comparisons attached.
